definitions: A stretching technique performed using voluntary muscle contraction without external assistance.
Stretching achieved by actively moving a limb through its range of motion.
A self-generated stretch relying on agonist muscle activation.
A stretch where the opposing muscle group provides the force.
Stretching performed without a partner or external load.
A mobility method emphasizing muscular control.
Stretching that improves strength through range.
ROM work driven by internal force production.
Activation of the primary muscle responsible for a movement.
Contraction of the muscle producing the intended joint action.
The force-generating muscle action driving motion.
Prime mover engagement during movement execution.
The dominant muscleâ€™s contraction in a task.
Force production by the main mover.
Neuromuscular activation of the movement initiator.
Relaxation of a muscle due to activation of its Golgi tendon organs.
A protective reflex that reduces muscle tension when force is high.
Inhibition of the same muscle experiencing tension.
GTO-mediated reduction in motor neuron activity.
A neuromuscular safety mechanism preventing excessive force.
Reflexive muscle relaxation following strong contraction.
Self-inhibition of a muscle under tension.
A mechanism exploited during PNF stretching.
A synovial joint permitting movement in all three planes.
A joint with a spherical head fitting into a cup-like socket.
A multiaxial joint such as the shoulder or hip.
A joint allowing flexion, extension, abduction, rotation, and circumduction.
The most mobile joint type in the body.
A joint sacrificing stability for mobility.
A joint enabling rotational and angular motion.
A stretching technique using rapid, bouncing movements.
Stretching that forces a limb beyond its normal ROM using momentum.
A high-velocity stretch that can activate the stretch reflex.
Stretching involving jerky or bouncing actions.
A stretch method generally discouraged for warm-ups.
Stretching that increases injury risk due to reflexive contraction.
ROM forcing via momentum rather than control.
A PNF stretch involving isometric contraction followed by relaxation.
Isometric contraction of the target muscle before stretching.
A flexibility method using neuromuscular reflexes.
A partner-assisted or self-applied PNF stretch.
The ability to move joints through full ROM during active movement.
Flexibility during motion rather than static positions.
A warm-up method emphasizing movement through ROM.
Stretching performed while the body is in motion.
Mobility work preparing tissues for activity.
Stretching that raises temperature and neural readiness.
The ability of tissue to return to its original length after deformation.
Reversible deformation of muscle or connective tissue.
Excessive connective tissue formation that restricts movement.
Thickening or scarring of soft tissues.
Reduced ROM due to collagen accumulation.
Connective tissue overgrowth after injury or inactivity.
Non-specific movement to prepare the body for exercise.
Warm-up phase focused on systemic readiness.
Activity raising heart rate and circulation.
Broad movement prep before specific drills.
A receptor located in tendons monitoring force.
A protective sensory organ preventing excessive tension.
A synovial joint permitting motion in one plane.
A joint allowing flexion and extension only.
Uniaxial joint such as the knee or elbow.
A joint with a door-hinge type movement.
Joint permitting angular motion in one direction.
Sensory receptors detecting muscle length and stretch speed.
Stretch-sensitive receptors initiating the stretch reflex.
Protective sensors responding to rapid stretch.
A stretch applied with external assistance.
ROM increase via partner, gravity, or apparatus.
Permanent deformation of connective tissue after prolonged stretch.
Enhanced neuromuscular performance following prior activation.
Temporary increase in force or power output.
Flexibility methods involving contraction and relaxation.
Stretching exploiting GTO and spindle responses.
The distance and direction a joint can move.
Angular displacement available at a joint.
Relaxation of an antagonist when the agonist contracts.
A stretch held at end ROM for a period of time.
An involuntary contraction in response to rapid stretch.
Protective reflex mediated by muscle spindles.
Automatic resistance to sudden muscle lengthening.
